titlestmt.titleproper: Medfield, Mass. First Parish Unitarian Church records, 1697-1970.
titlestmt.author: Jules Thomson

seriesstmt.p: Portions of this collection are part of New England's Hidden Histories. Digital historical representations of these portions of the collection can be viewed online.

conventiondeclaration.citation: Describing Archives: A Content Standard, Second Edition

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday March 3, 2022 at 18:51
Some adjustments made to the physical arrangement of materials; "Miscellaneous records, circa 1700-1799" added to the finding aid.

did.unittitle: Medfield, Mass. First Parish Unitarian Church records, 1697-1970.
did.abstract: The First Parish Church was founded in 1751 shortly after the incorporation of the town of Medfield. Rev. John Wilson was the first pastor. A second meeting house was constructed in 1706. The third and current meetinghouse was built in 1789. In 1813 the town and the parish were legally separated with members of the church incorporated as The First Parish. In 1827 a group of members of the First Parish petitioned for permission to withdraw from the First Parish, which was becoming increasingly Unitarian, in order to form an Orthodox church. The original First Parish church was subsequently known as the First Parish Unitarian church. The records of the First Parish Church include both church administrative documentation and some personal records such as legal and financial materials.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

Digital Reproductions are protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use the Digital Reproductions in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. In addition, no permission is required from the Congregational Library & Archives for educational uses. For other uses, you need to obtain permission from the Congregational Library & Archives. For additional information regarding copyright, please consult the Congregational Library & Archives' Digital Collections Copyright & Use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Medfield, Mass. First Parish Unitarian Church records, 1697-1970, RG5309. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were permanently loaned to the Congregational Library & Archives by the First Parish Unitarian Church (Medfield, Mass.) in April 2018; 2018-09

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: Records within this collection were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions may be accessed online through our digital archive.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional accruals are expected for this collection in the form of full-text transcription. There is no anticipated date for this accrual.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and described by Jules Thomson, August 2019, using DACS Second edition.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The First Parish Church dates back to the beginning of the town of Medfield in 1649, in which settlers from Dedham and Braintree, Mass. requested the incorporation of a new town by the General Court which was subsequently granted in May of 1651. They founded the Medfield Church of Christ in the same year, calling Rev. John Wilson as their first pastor.

The second minister was Rev. Joseph Baxter, a Harvard graduate and native of Braintree, Massachusetts, who served from 1697-1745. During his ministry the church membership grew from 65 to 375, and a second meeting house was constructed in 1706.

During the pastorate of the fourth minister Rev. Thomas Prentiss, which lasted from 1770-1814, a third meetinghouse was built, dating to 1789. As of 2019, a heavily remodeled version of this building is still standing, and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The specifications for the wooden frame of the building are given in detail in the town records and include details of the heavy timbers used in construction, which were hand hewn oak measuring 14 inches square. The building's tower was 52 feet high and surmounted by a belfry and cupola. In 1809 the inside of the church was refurbished, with seats in the body of the meeting house being taken up and replaced with pews, as well as the creation of a segregated gallery seating area for non-white parishioners.

In 1813 the town and the parish began to be legally separated. The members of the church incorporated as The First Parish. In 1816 the trustees of the Medfield Ministerial Fund, Inc. were granted a charter and by-laws by the General Court. The first Sunday school was organized in 1818, officiated entirely by women, with the wife of Rev. Thomas Prentiss playing an active role in its administration.

In 1827 a group of members of the First Parish petitioned for permission to withdraw from the First Parish, which was becoming increasingly Unitarian, in order to form an Orthodox church. An ecclesiastical council was called and granted their request. The Orthodox Church of Medfield was organized officially on February 6, 1828 with 17 total members, and is still active today as the United Church of Christ in Medfield.

The original First Parish church was subsequently known as the First Parish Unitarian church from 1828 onwards. The meeting house was extensively remodeled again in 1839, including a complete reorientation of the front of the building from east to south, and the construction of a larger spire. During the hurricane of 1938, the taller spire which had been added when the building was remodeled in 1839 was destroyed, and remains un-replaced.

By the 1970s the congregation had diminished to 10 members and was in danger of dissolution. Growth increased in the following decades, however, to the extent that the Unitarian Universalist Association granted the church an award in recognition of their revitalization. The church continues to serve the Medfield community today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records of the First Parish Church in Medfield include a broad array of both church administrative documentation and some personal records such as legal and financial materials. There is a single bound volume of church records dating from 1738-1880. Other administrative documentation includes a folder of loose records found inside the volume, official church correspondence, membership records, meeting minutes, relations, and a collection of 17th-18th century prayer requests. Also included are records relating to the ministry, including correspondence from ministers, and a volume of sermons spanning several decades from the 1740s-1780s. Personal records include legal and financial records, and a single item of personal correspondence regarding provisions for a ship. Additionally, a small volume of printed materials consisting of a 19th-century order of service and a newspaper cutting from 1970 detailing preservation of the colonial-era relation of faith documents within the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files have been arranged in chronological order by start date, and their contents are ordered chronologically, except in the case of the relation of faith documents, which are ordered alphabetically by surname.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: To access digital materials on our digital archive, it is strongly recommended that you use the latest available version of Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Safari (Apple).

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Henderson, J. Hardy. Historical sketch of the First Congregational Parish (Unitarian), 1651-1951. Medfield, 1951. 17.11.1 M46.65 FIRPUC
"Our History." First Parish UU of Medfield, MA. Accessed August 13, 2019. https://www.firstparishmedfield.org/our-history/

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains relations of faith by parishioners seeking to join the church in Medfield, with surnames beginning with A-G. The documents are organized alphabetically by last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains relations of parishioners with surnames beginning with H-Z, as well as unattributed relations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These documents relate directly to the office of the ministry and include correspondence of Rev. Joseph Baxter regarding dissatisfaction with his ministry, a letter of acceptance of the ministerial call from Rev. Thomas Prentice, and an undated sermon fragment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains letters regarding dismissals, admonitions, and excommunication of Medfield church members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains land deeds, wills, and a court summons. These include a deed from David Whitmarsh to Nathaniel Bosworth (5/15/1789), a fragmentary will and inventory by a member of the Baxter family (undated), and a court summons by Jonathan Bishop (Justice of the Peace for the Commonwealth of Mass.) to members of the First Congregational Society In Medfield (12/3/1842).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains financial records relating to the church and its parishioners, including receipts by John Fisher for payment by John Baxter (10/28/1765), by Edward Davis for payment by John Baxtor (2/2/1753), and by Jonathan Fiske for payment by Heirs of John Baxter (1832). Also included are lists of subscribers for payments toward the spire of Unitarian Meetinghouse and toward the purchasing of an organ for First Congregational Meetinghouse in Medfield (undated).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains the administrative records of the church as well as the vital records of the church's members. The volume contains meeting minutes, records of important votes, marriage records, baptismal records, necrologies, lists of admitted members and founding documents such as the church covenant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose pages of meeting minutes for the church in Medfield, and correspondence with descriptions of meeting minutes and associated votes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains seven manuscript sermons, unattributed but written largely in the same hand. The verse text, locations, and dates are as follows:
Matthew 4:7 (first preached at Medfield on February 24, 1744/5)
Psalm 116.4 (first preached at Medfield on June 29, 1746)
James 4.13.14 (first preached at Medfield on January 3, 1747/8)
James 4.15 (first preached at Medfield on January 3, 1747/8)
Amos 12.4.5. (first preached at Medfield on January 28 1747/8)
James 3.15 (first preached at Medfield on May 17, 1747)
Mark 6:3 (first preached at Medfield on May 22, 1748)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a number of manuscript sermons, unattributed but written largely in the same hand. The verses, locations, and dates are as follows:
Deuteronomy 32 (first preached at Medfield on June 25, 1750)
James 1:21 (first preached at Medfield on August 5, 1750)
James 1:21 (first preached at Medfield on August 12, 1750)
James 3:17-18 (first preached at Medfield on March 15, 1752)
Proverbs 22:17-22 (first preached Medfield on June 28, 1752)
Matthew 13:36-44 (first preached at Medfield on January 21, 1753)
James 1:27 (first preached at Medfield on August 12, 1753)
James 1:27 (first preached at Medfield on August 12, 1753)
James 4:8 (first preached at Medfield on March 31, 1754)
James 5:12 (first preached at Medfield on June 29, 1755)
James 5:12 (first preached at Medfield on July 13, 1755)
Romans 10:9-10 (first preached at Medfield on January 25, 1756)
Exodus 20:8-11 (first preached at Roxbury on February 1, 1756)
Amos 4:7-8 (first preached on June 20, 1756)
1 Peter 5:7 (first preached November 14, 1756)
Psalm 103:19 (first preached at Roxbury on March 13, 1757)
James 5:7 (first preached at Medfield on June 12, 1757)
Romans 2:13 (first preached October, 1757)
Luke 2:10-11 (first preached at Roxbury on December 25, 1757)
James 1:12 (first preached on January 8, 1758)
Matthew 22:1-14 (first preached at Roxbury on March 18, 1759)
Joshua 1 (first preached at Medfield on 7 May 27, 1759)
James 4:6 (first preached at Medfield on August 19, 1759)
1 Corinthians 15:58 (first preached at Roxbury on September 23, 1759)
James 4:4 (first preached at Medfield on November 25, 1759)
James 4:4 (first preached at Medfield on November 25, 1759)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a number of manuscript sermons, unattributed but written largely in the same hand. The individual sermon texts and dates are as follows:
Psalm 139:9-100 (first preached June 8, 1760)
James 1:26 (first preached May 10, 1761)
James 5:17-18 (first preached July 19, 1761)
John 21 (first preached October 17, 1762)
Matthew 18:1-14 (first preached January 23, 1763)
Matthew 19: 16-26 (first preached February 27, 1763)
Psalm 91:16 (first preached March 4, 1764)
James 5:13 (first preached March 10, 1765)
James 5:13 (first preached March 10, 1765)
[verse missing] (first preached February 16, 1766)
1 Thessalonians 2:13 (first preached February 23, 1766)
Proverbs 3:3-4 (first preached August 31, 1766)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains a number of manuscript sermons, unattributed but written in the same hand. The verses, locations and dates are ennumerated below:
Isaiah 57:20-21 (first preached at Roxbury on August 18, 1771)
Acts 3:20-26 (first preached at Roxbury on November 1, 1772)
Acts 4:13-20 (first preached at Roxbury on November 29, 1772)
Acts 5:1-11 (first preached at Roxbury on January 17, 1773)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a single manuscript sermon on Psalm 47:7. The sermon is attributed to "Rev. Thomas Prentiss" (Thomas Prentice)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a number of manuscript sermons, unattributed but written largely in the same hand. All but three of the sermons are missing pages or are otherwise fragmentary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose records found between pages 167-168 of the bound Church record book (1738-1880). They include a piece of correspondence to the church by Thomas Prentice dated 1770, loose meeting minutes dated 1817-1860, and two loose pages of pencil notes relating to the bound volume of records, with page annotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains official correspondence both to and from the church in Medfield, largely constituting letters of invitation to ecclesiastical councils and the ordinations of new ministers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a single item of personal correspondence, from "N.B." to "Captain Turner" of the sloop Experiment. The writer details his provision of the ship with a barrel of sweet potatoes and provides instructions for cooking them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains printed materials, consisting of an order of service for the installation service of Rev. Solon Bush, and a 1970 newspaper clipping detailing the preservation of the church's relations of faith (1697-1788) by Rev. Robert A. Thayer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains prayer requests likely dating to the 17th-18th centuries, with the names of parishioners making the request and a brief description of the desired prayer. They include prayers for safe passage, protection of relatives during military service, bolstering of personal faith, and sanctification of deaths occurring in the family.
